TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit LoginName extends System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebControl

Docs.summary: Displays the value of the property.

remarks.format:
## Remarks In this topic: - [Introduction](#introduction) - [Accessibility](#accessibility) - [Declarative Syntax](#declarative_syntax) ## Introduction By default, the control displays the name contained in the property of the class. If the `System.Web.UI.Page.User.Identity.Name` property is empty, the control is not rendered. > [!NOTE] > If you are not familiar with the set of login controls available in ASP.NET, see [ASP.NET Login Controls Overview](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ac032230-6469-4b03-b68d-03ef2643a24d) before continuing. For a list of other topics related to login controls and membership, see [Managing Users by Using Membership](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/824c3a24-f0af-427c-a652-0d2d1e9397cd). To change the text displayed by the control, set the property. > [!NOTE] > The control cannot be used outside the `
` tag on a Web page. Specifically, the cannot be used to put the user's name in the title of a page. ## Accessibility For information about how to configure this control so that it generates markup that conforms to accessibility standards, see [Accessibility in Visual Studio and ASP.NET](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/7e3ce9c4-6b7d-4fb1-94b5-72cf2a44fe13) and [ASP.NET Controls and Accessibility](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/847a37e3-ce20-41da-b0d3-7dfb0fdae9a0). ## Declarative Syntax ``` ``` ## Examples The following code example shows how to use the class on a page. Clicking the button changes the display format.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Creates a new instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginName> control.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual string FormatString { get; set; }

Docs.summary: Provides a format item string to display.
Docs.value: A string containing format items for displaying the user's name. The default value is "{0}".

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginName.FormatString%2A> property contains a standard text format string that displays the user's name on the Web page. The string "{0}" indicates where in the string the user's name is inserted. The following table describes the available property settings.
|Property setting|Behavior| |----------------------|--------------| |Default ("{0}")|The user's name is displayed when the user is logged on; otherwise, nothing is displayed.| |<xref:System.String.Empty>|Same as default. To hide the control, set the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.Visible%2A> property to `false`.| |"Welcome to my site, {0}."|Displays the string "Welcome to my site, *username*." when the user is logged in. When the user is not logged in, nothing is displayed.| |"Welcome to my site."|When the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginName.FormatString%2A> property is set to a string, the string is displayed when the user is logged in. Because the string does not contain "{0}", the user's name is not displayed. When the user is not logged in, nothing is displayed.|
The value of this property, when set, can be saved automatically to a resource file by using a designer tool. For more information, see <xref:System.ComponentModel.LocalizableAttribute> and [Globalization and Localization](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/8ef3838e-9d05-4236-9dd0-ceecff9df80d).
## Examples The following code example shows how to use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginName.FormatString%2A> property on a page. Clicking the button changes the display format.
<!-- TODO: review snippet reference [!code-csharp[LoginNameTextFormat#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/LoginNameTextFormat/CS/loginnametextformatcs.aspx#1)] --> <!-- TODO: review snippet reference [!code-vb[LoginNameTextFormat#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/LoginNameTextFormat/VB/loginnametextformatvb.aspx#1)] -->

Docs.exception: The format string is not valid.

Docs.summary: Renders the HTML closing tag of the control to the specified writer.
Gets a value that indicates whether the control should set the attribute of the rendered HTML element to "disabled" when the control's property is .
Docs.value: if the property indicates an ASP.NET version lower than 4.0; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks This property indicates how ASP.NET should render HTML for a control when the control is disabled. If this property is `true`, ASP.NET renders a `disabled` attribute when a control is disabled. If this property is `false`, ASP.NET renders a `class` attribute when a control is disabled. For more information, see <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebControl.SupportsDisabledAttribute%2A?displayProperty=fullName>.
